Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Expectation2: Maintain a safe and O39ean work environment.
Situation2: You notice a small, contained liquid spill in a walkway that needs to be O39eaned up immediately to prevent slips.
Story: I stood at the edge of the construction site, sweat clinging to my brow, when my phone buzzed. Glancing over, I saw my younger brother, skateboard in hand, grinning at the top of the old, cracked ramp behind our house. He was about to try that trick he’d been talking about for weeks, the one I’d warned him was too dangerous. As his older sibling, I was supposed to look out for him, make sure he didn’t do anything reckless. But just then, out of the corner of my eye, I spotted a slick, shimmering puddle on the walkway near the scaffolding. As a laborer, I knew the rules—any spill, no matter how small, had to be cleaned up right away. If someone slipped, it’d be on me. My heart pounded as I looked from the ramp to the spill, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in. My brother’s safety, my coworkers’ safety—both depended on me, but I couldn’t be in two places at once.
